Prompt:
Example 1:
As Johnson worked on math problems with the other female computers, she would ask questions. She didn't want to just do the work — she wanted to know the "hows" and the "whys," and then the "why nots." By asking questions, Johnson began to stand out.
Women were not allowed to attend meetings with the male engineers and scientists. Johnson wanted to go to these meetings to learn more about the projects, so she went. She became known for her training in geometry and began to work with teams made up of men. Eventually, she was recognized as a leader, and the men increasingly relied on her to have the answers they needed.
In 1958, NACA officially became NASA. Shortly thereafter, Johnson became part of the space team. She began calculating the flight path, or trajectory path, for the rocket to put the first American in space in 1961. That American was astronaut Alan Shepard. The engineers knew when and where they wanted Shepard's space capsule to land, but the tricky part was to calculate when and where the rocket would have to launch. Johnson figured it out!

Example 2:
When Naomi saw that Ruth loved her so much, she forgot how tired and hungry she was, and the two journeyed on together until they came to Bethlehem in Judah in the beginning of the barley harvest. There was no famine in Bethlehem. The fields were full of waving grain, and busy servants were reaping it and gathering it up to bind into sheaves. Above all were the fields of the rich man, Boaz, shining with barley and corn.
Naomi and Ruth came to the edge of the fields and watched the busy reapers. They saw that after each sheaf was bound, and each pile of corn was stacked, a little grain fell, unnoticed, to the ground. Ruth said to Naomi: "Let me go to the field and glean the ears of corn after them." And Naomi said to her, "Go, my daughter." And she went, and came and gleaned in the field after the reapers.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'astronomy' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 100 words. 
Astronomy is the study of stars and the universe. When we look up at the night sky, we see many twinkling lights. These are the stars. By studying the stars, astronomers can learn about the universe and how it began. The universe is so big that it's hard to understand. But by studying the stars and other things in space, astronomers can learn more about the universe and its many secrets. They can even use special telescopes to see things that are too far away to see with our eyes.

Olivia was not allowed to join the astronomy club because she was a girl, but she went anyway. She became known for her knowledge of constellations and soon was working with the other members. Olivia began to track the movements of the planets, and the club members relied on her to have the answers. She figured out that the planetarium's new telescope was ready to be used and suggested they use it. Olivia's skills made her a valuable member of the team.

Prompt:
Example 1:
As Johnson worked on math problems with the other female computers, she would ask questions. She didn't want to just do the work — she wanted to know the "hows" and the "whys," and then the "why nots." By asking questions, Johnson began to stand out.
Women were not allowed to attend meetings with the male engineers and scientists. Johnson wanted to go to these meetings to learn more about the projects, so she went. She became known for her training in geometry and began to work with teams made up of men. Eventually, she was recognized as a leader, and the men increasingly relied on her to have the answers they needed.
In 1958, NACA officially became NASA. Shortly thereafter, Johnson became part of the space team. She began calculating the flight path, or trajectory path, for the rocket to put the first American in space in 1961. That American was astronaut Alan Shepard. The engineers knew when and where they wanted Shepard's space capsule to land, but the tricky part was to calculate when and where the rocket would have to launch. Johnson figured it out!

Example 2:
When Naomi saw that Ruth loved her so much, she forgot how tired and hungry she was, and the two journeyed on together until they came to Bethlehem in Judah in the beginning of the barley harvest. There was no famine in Bethlehem. The fields were full of waving grain, and busy servants were reaping it and gathering it up to bind into sheaves. Above all were the fields of the rich man, Boaz, shining with barley and corn.
Naomi and Ruth came to the edge of the fields and watched the busy reapers. They saw that after each sheaf was bound, and each pile of corn was stacked, a little grain fell, unnoticed, to the ground. Ruth said to Naomi: "Let me go to the field and glean the ears of corn after them." And Naomi said to her, "Go, my daughter." And she went, and came and gleaned in the field after the reapers.

Astronomy is the study of the universe and its many mysteries. It helps us understand the stars, planets, and galaxies that fill our sky. By studying astronomy, we can learn more about the world we live in and its many wonders. It's a fascinating field.

Astronomy is the study of the universe and its objects. Astronomers, who are scientists who study the universe, observe the stars, planets, and galaxies. They use telescopes and other tools to learn more about the universe. They also study the movements and behaviors of the stars and planets. By studying the universe, astronomers can learn about the past and present of our solar system and the universe as a whole. Their discoveries help us better understand the vastness of space and the mysteries that lie within. Astronomers are curious about what lies beyond our planet. They want to explore and discover the secrets of the universe.  Astronomers are like detectives of the universe, seeking clues and solving mysteries. By studying the universe, we can gain a better understanding of our place in the universe and the mysteries that lie beyond our planet.
